Instruction:
Task Description: Implement a TCP server in Go that handles multiple client connections concurrently, with configurable timeouts and connection management. The server should be able to start, accept connections, read data from clients, and properly shut down while cleaning up resources.

Struct Description: The Server struct represents a TCP server with configurable network settings, timeouts, and connection management capabilities. It maintains state about active connections and provides methods to start, serve, and manage the server lifecycle.

Fields:

Addr: [string] - The network address to listen on (e.g., ":8080")
Net: [string] - The network type (e.g., "tcp", "tcp4", "tcp6")
Handler: [Handler] - The handler for processing incoming requests
ReadTimeout: [time.Duration] - Maximum duration for reading a request
WriteTimeout: [time.Duration] - Maximum duration for writing a response
IdleTimeout: [func() time.Duration] - Function returning idle connection timeout
lock: [sync.RWMutex] - Protects concurrent access to server state
started: [bool] - Indicates if server is running
shutdown: [chan struct{}] - Channel for shutdown signaling
conns: [map[net.Conn]struct{}] - Map of active connections

Methods:

ListenAndServe: [Name]() -> [error] - Starts the server and begins accepting connections
serveTCP: [Name](net.Listener) -> [error] - Main TCP serving loop that accepts connections
serveTCPConn: [Name](*sync.WaitGroup, net.Conn) -> [] - Handles an individual TCP connection
readTCP: [Name](net.Conn, time.Duration) -> ([]byte, error) - Reads data from a TCP connection
init: [Name]() -> [] - Initializes server resources
isStarted: [Name]() -> [bool] - Checks if server is running
getIdleTimeout: [Name]() -> [time.Duration] - Returns idle timeout duration
getReadTimeout: [Name]() -> [time.Duration] - Returns read timeout duration
